journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine

title-group.article-title: Bilateral asymmetry in microarchitecture of trabecular bone in male c57bl/6 mouse tibia: implication for experimental sample size estimations

article-meta.aff: 1Research Team, Korea Orthopedics & Rehabilitation Engineering Center, Incheon, Republic of Korea
2Department of Biomedical Engineering and Yonsei-Fraunhofer Medical Device Lab, Yonsei University, Republic of Korea

author-notes.corresp: Han Sung Kim, Department of Biomedical Engineering and Yonsei-Fraunhofer Medical Device Lab, Yonsei University, 220-710, Republic of Korea. Email: hanskim@yonsei.ac.kr

abstract.p: This study aimed to determine whether there is bilateral asymmetry between the left and right tibiae in the microarchitectural characteristics of the trabecular bone and estimate a moderate sample size for detections of such bilateral differences. The left and right tibiae of 20 C57BL/6 mice (12 weeks old) were scanned by micro-computed tomography, and the structural parameters of the trabecular bone were measured. There were significant differences in the structural parameters between the left and right tibiae (p<0.05); specifically, the microarchitecture was greater in quantity and quality in the left tibia than in the right tibia. Moreover, the percent of bilateral differences between the left and right tibiae ranged from 2.26% to 22.52%. For most of the structural parameters except for trabecular bone thickness (Tb.Th) and trabecular bone separation (Tb.Sp), the 20 mice involved in this study were enough to detect differences. These results show that the directional left–right asymmetry in the microarchitecture of the trabecular bone may exist despite the samples being from an inbred strain. Furthermore, we estimated a sample size for detections of such differences between the left and right tibiae.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Biophysical stimuli can improve regeneration or healing of defective bones. However, studies of the effects of biophysical stimuli on osteoporotic trabecular bone have provided contradictory results: positive1–3 versus not positive4–6 effects. The differences in findings can be attributed to several factors, including differences in the characteristics of each biophysical stimulus investigated. Bone adaptation to biophysical stimuli is modulated by the characteristics of various biophysical stimuli (e.g. stimulus type (dynamic vs. static loading), frequency, magnitude).7–11

In addition to differences in the characteristics of biophysical stimuli studied previously, contradictory findings could also be because of differences in study populations. Differences in genetic background, sex, and age may affect study results.12–16 Additionally, the mechanosensitivity of bone changes with aging.9,10,16 The magnitude and rate of bone adaptation to unloading or mechanical loading is dependent upon bone status or condition prior to unloading.17–19

Differences in the experimental design may also contribute to the diversity of trabecular bone adaptations to biophysical stimuli. Numerous studies evaluating the effects of biophysical stimuli for treating bone loss have used the contralateral hindlimb as the internal control.1,6 These studies are based on a premise that no difference in bone biomechanical characteristics of trabecular bone exists naturally between the left and right hindlimbs. However, few studies have attempted to verify this premise. Several studies have shown bilateral symmetry of biomechanical properties for bone in the ovine tibia,20 the canine distal femur,21 the mouse femur,22 and the human metacarpal,23 but these studies focused only on cortical bone. To the best of our knowledge, few studies have been conducted on symmetries of the trabecular bone between the left and right femurs.24 However, this used dogs but not small animals.

Therefore, the aim of this study was to assess the bilateral asymmetry in the microarchitectural characteristics of the trabecular bones in bilateral limbs of C57BL/6 mice, a commonly used inbred strain of laboratory mice for investigation of bone adaptation to unloading or biophysical stimuli. Furthermore, we have suggested a moderate sample size for detections of the differences between the left and right tibiae.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: All procedures were performed using a protocol approved by the Yonsei University Animal Care Committee. For the study, 12-week-old male C57BL/6 mice (n = 20, weight = approximately 24.3 g) were used. The left and right tibiae of all mice were scanned at a spatial resolution of 18 µm3 using in vivo micro-computed tomography (µ-CT, SkyScan 1076; Bruker microCT, Aartselaar, Belgium). Scanning parameters were set to 85 kV voltage, 118 µA current, 2065 ms exposure time, and a 0.7° rotation step. General anesthesia with isoflurane (Hana Pharmaceutical, Seoul, Republic of Korea) was used for all scanning.

Structural parameters for trabecular bone were quantified using the trabecular bone volume fraction (BV/TV, %), trabecular bone thickness (Tb.Th, µm), trabecular bone separation (Tb.Sp, µm), trabecular number per unit length (Tb.N, 1/mm), structure model index (SMI), and connectivity density (Conn.Dn). For analysis of these values, the regions of interest for trabecular bone from µ-CT images were determined using contouring methods, and then the volume of interest was determined by a 1.8-mm length of bone, located 0.54 mm below the growth plate, as reported in our previous studies.1,15 All analyses were randomly performed in a day by an identical researcher.

Paired t-tests were carried out to assess the left–right difference in the structural parameters at each time (p<0.05). These analyses were performed using SPSS 17.0 (IBM, Armonk, NY, USA). To assess the bilateral symmetry of the tibiae, the percent bilateral differences (PBD) for the structural parameters were calculated as
In order to estimate the dispersion of structural parameters, the coefficient of variation (CV) was calculated as

A post hoc power analysis was performed to verify the statistical power for each value as a function of 0.05 (the significance level, α). Furthermore, an a priori power analysis was carried out to compute the minimum number of animals required to detect a significant left–right difference for each value (α = 0.05, 1−β = 0.8) based on the results of this study. These power analyses were calculated by using G*POWER 3.1.25,26

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The structural parameters and PBD are shown in Table 1. There were significant differences for BV/TV, Tb.Th, Tb.N, SMI, and Conn.Dn between the left and right tibiae (p = 0.0007, 0.0313, 0.0006, 0.0018, 0.0001, respectively). However, no significant difference in Tb.Sp was observed between the left and right tibiae (p = 0.0928). These differences between the left and right tibiae in the microarchitecture of the trabecular bone were confirmed visually in Figure 1. PBD ranged from 2.26% for Tb.Th to 22.52% for BV/TV (Table 1). Additionally, all the CVs for structural parameters in both the left and right tibiae were lower when compared to all the values for PBD corresponding to each structural parameter (Figure 2).

caption.p: Structural parameters and their percent differences represented as mean (standard deviation) (number of animals = 20).

fn.p: BV/TV: trabecular bone volume fraction; Tb.Th: trabecular bone thickness; Tb.Sp: trabecular bone separation; Tb.N: trabecular number per unit length; SMI: structure model index; Conn.Dn: connectivity density; PBD: percent bilateral differences.

caption.p: Bilateral difference between the left and right tibiae in the three-dimensional microarchitecture of trabecular bone for all mice.
The coefficient of variation (standard deviation/average × 100%) for each structural parameter and PBD.

BV/TV: trabecular bone volume fraction; Tb.Th: trabecular bone thickness; Tb.Sp: trabecular bone separation; Tb.N: trabecular number per unit length; SMI: structure model index; Conn.Dn: connectivity density; PBD: percent bilateral differences.

sec.p: The effect size and statistical power for each value in this study are shown in Table 2. The effect size and statistical power varied for each structural parameter. In particular, there were higher values of statistical power for BV/TV, Tb.N, SMI, and Conn.Dn than 0.80 but relatively lower values for Tb.Th and Tb.Sp.

caption.p: Effect size (measurement of the magnitude for the bilateral differences), statistical power for each structural parameter, and BMD (number of animals = 20, α = 0.05).

fn.p: BV/TV: trabecular bone volume fraction, Tb.Th: trabecular bone thickness, Tb.Sp: trabecular bone separation, Tb.N: trabecular number per unit length, SMI: structure model index, and Conn.Dn: connectivity density.

sec.p: On the basis of our findings in the structural parameters, a sample size was estimated in order to detect a difference between the left and right tibiae (α = 0.05, 1−β = 0.8; Figure 3). Sample sizes varied in each structural parameter. The estimated sample sizes for BV/TV, Tb.N, SMI, and Conn.Dn were below 17 (the number in this study) while that for Tb.Th and Tb.Sp were 45 and 90, respectively.

caption.p: The total sample size (animal) for minimum detectable differences for each structural parameter (α = 0.05, 1−β = 0.8).

BV/TV: trabecular bone volume fraction; Tb.Th: trabecular bone thickness; Tb.Sp: trabecular bone separation; Tb.N: trabecular number per unit length; SMI: structure model index; Conn.Dn: connectivity density.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Although previous studies have reported detecting bilateral symmetry in cortical bone 20–23 as well as trabecular bone,24 to the best of our knowledge, there have been no studies on the symmetry of trabecular bone in small animals. This study aimed to assess the differences in microarchitectural characteristics of trabecular bone in both limbs of C57BL/6 male mice commonly used for investigating bone adaptations.

BV/TV, Tb.Th, Tb.N, and Conn.Dn were higher and SMI was lower in the left tibia than in the right tibia, suggesting that the trabecular bone is greater in quantity and quality (trabeculae thickness and shape, connectivity) in the left tibia than in the right tibia. These results imply that the microarchitecture of trabecular bone might be different between the left and right tibiae. These results are inconsistent with the study by Kuhn et al.,24 which indicated that there was symmetry between the left and right hindlimbs. This result may be attributed to differences in the subjects in that mice were used in this study versus dogs in the study by Kuhn et al. Additionally, CVs of PBD for each structural parameter tended to be higher than the CVs of values for each structural parameter. This result suggests that interindividual asymmetry between the left and right tibiae in the microarchitecture of trabecular bone may be relatively higher than the interindividual asymmetry in the microarchitecture of trabecular bone between each side of the tibiae. Furthermore, such bilateral differences might be directional asymmetry rather than fluctuating asymmetry because PBDs of the structural parameters were far from zero.27

In this study, a relatively small sample size (20 mice, 40 tibiae) was used. Thus, the statistical analyses might possess a β error, leading to insufficient statistical power. To verify the statistical power, we carried out a post hoc power analysis.25,26,28 Most of the structural parameters in 12-week-old samples have higher power values. These results indicate that our statistical analyses could exclude the possibility of a β error and thus might be reliable for the detection of left–right differences.

Based on the results, we estimated the total sample size for minimum detectable differences for each structural parameter. The total sample size was different according to each parameter. The 20 mice used in this study might detect asymmetry in most of the structural parameters for trabecular bone, except for Tb.Th and Tb.Sp between the left and right tibiae. However, further studies are required to confirm the asymmetry in different species, sexes, and ages of animal.

This study did not verify the mechanisms related to the left–right asymmetry of the tibia. Shiratori and Hamada29 stated that left–right asymmetry was present at the embryo level and was established from the embryonic period. Embryonic asymmetry occurs in three steps: (1) a symmetry-breaking phenomenon in the node, (2) patterning of the lateral plate mesoderm, and (3) asymmetric organogenesis.29 At the tissue or organ level, asymmetry is caused by three mechanisms: (1) directional looping mechanisms (e.g. the heart and gut), (2) differential branching (e.g. the lung), and (3) one-sided regression (e.g. blood vessels).29 Previous studies have shown differential rates of bone homeostasis, bone formation and bone resorption at different sites in the same body under the same conditions.1,30 These phenomena may be due to the nature of cells and may relate to positional information and patterning.31,32 Moreover, a genetic basis may be one of the factors regulating the left–right asymmetry of tibiae due to a directional asymmetry shown in this study.33 As a result, developmental factors and/or the nature of cells may contribute to the natural left–right asymmetry in the microarchitectural characteristics of trabecular bone in the tibia.

In conclusion, a left–right asymmetry in the biomechanical properties of trabecular bone may exist and the 20 mice used in this study may detect this asymmetry in the microarchitecture for trabecular bone. Thus, the contralateral bone as an internal control should be considered with caution in the interpretation of results from such studies. Additionally, our findings may imply the importance of considering baseline bone status for investigation of bone adaptation. Furthermore, the presence of left–right asymmetry may be responsible for the differing effects of bone adaptations to biophysical stimuli.
